Students ran, hid as man opened fire at Calif. college

A rampage at Oikos University left seven dead, three wounded, trapped some in a building and forced others to flee for their lives, police said. (AP)

Boston University’s independent student newspaper came under intense criticism for an April Fools’ edition that made light of rape. (Boston Globe)

Suburbs, islands home to healthiest

Martha’s Vineyard and Nantucket residents are among Massachusetts’ healthiest, while those in Hampden and Suffolk counties, are the least fit, a report says. (Globe)

Now online: a link across generations

The National Archives posted 3.9 million pages of records, marking the first time original 1940 Census forms have been released online. (Boston Globe)
  • Interest in 1940 US census paralyzes website

22% cut in haul of cod ordered

In a move that will bring increased hardship to a struggling industry, regulators reduced the amount of cod local fishermen can catch this season. (Boston Globe)

Bay State leads the
fight on right to marry

Mass. will become the first state to go before a US appeals court to challenge a federal law that defines marriage as a union only of a man and a woman.
Opinion | Kevin Cullen

The pulse of Red Sox Nation

More than 80 percent of Massachusetts voters identify themselves as Red Sox fans, a figure that pollster Tom Jensen said is unique in the US.

Whistle-blower is still on the case

Harry Markopolos is still pursuing new abuses after sounding an alarm about Bernard Madoff, but says he no longer fears physical attack.

Crunching feedback into data

Joe Delfino, 20, is an undergraduate at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and co-developer of the start-up software company Texifter.
Art Review

Making it real, color by color

The exhibit of prints by Janet Fish at the Smith College Museum of Art is cogent and lucidly instructive.
Album Review

Dr. John’s latest mixes past, present

Dr. John’s new album is a sly homage to the classic records he’s been making since the late 1960s.
Opinion | Joanna Weiss

Marriage, managers, ‘mommy wars’

A new research paper posits a husband-centric explanation for why women are so underrepresented on corporate boards and in executive suites.

Health & Wellness

Six steps to lower skin cancer risk

A new Mayo Clinic study found that rates of melanoma, the deadliest skin cancer, have increased eight-fold among women in one Minnesota county and four-fold among young men over the past 40 years.
